page.title: 02CLIFFS AND FORESHORE PETT
page.content: The cliffs at Pett, about 150 million years old, are part of the Hastings Beds, sandstone with clay underlay. Clay saturated with water results in landslipping.{Erosion}here has been speeded up because of shingle movement. Chunks which fall at Cliff End are usually roughly 2m x 4m, following the Wedge theory, the fall being proportional to the height of the cliff. The sea seems to have reached parts of the present shoreline over 5000 years ago. Evidence comes from the foreshore where clay is covered by freshwater peat and a layer of ancient tree stumps and timber. {Radiocarbon dating}suggests that a forest probably grew in a swamp near the shore 5200 to 5300 years ago. Also visible at low tide is the outline of the British warship 'Anne' lost in Battle of Beachy Head (1690)
